script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I’ve got a question that’s been nagging at me for days. In Moses 1, God calls Moses 'my son' and reveals incredible truths about his identity. But then Satan comes along and immediately challenges that with, 'Moses, son of man, worship me' in verse 12. Why such a direct attack on identity, and what’s at stake here?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Oh, Sarah, you’ve hit on the core of a cosmic battle. Satan’s attack on Moses’s identity isn’t random—it’s strategic. If he can make Moses forget who he really is, a son of God, then he can derail God’s entire plan for him. Let’s unpack this, because what’s at stake isn’t just Moses’s mission, but a pattern that echoes through every dispensation.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, a pattern? That sounds intriguing. What do you mean by that, and how does it connect to Moses’s experience?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly. Notice this: in Moses 1:4, God declares, 'Behold, thou art my son.' It’s a powerful affirmation of divine identity. But Satan counters in verse 12 with 'son of man,' trying to reduce Moses to a mere mortal. This tension—between divine identity and worldly doubt—plays out in ancient Israel, in Christ’s ministry, and even in our modern lives.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s fascinating, but how does it look from those different perspectives? I mean, how did ancient Israel see this identity struggle compared to, say, how Christ addressed it?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great question. In ancient Israel, identity as God’s covenant people was central—think of the promises to Abraham about his seed. They often forgot their divine calling, much like Moses could have under Satan’s pressure. Fast forward to Christ, and He embodies the ultimate divine identity, calling God 'Father' and teaching us to do the same, as in Matthew 6:9.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And today? How do modern Saints fit into this?

script.speaker: David
script.text: In our day, President Russell M. Nelson has emphasized this same truth. In his talk 'Choices for Eternity,' he says, 'The first thing [the Lord] would make sure you understand is your true identity.' Satan still tries to confuse us with worldly labels, just as he did with Moses, but recognizing ourselves as children of God shapes every choice we make.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that connection across time. But let’s dive deeper into this pattern of identity. Can you trace it across more dispensations for us?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely. Let’s start with Abraham in Abraham 3:22-23. Here, the Lord shows Abraham the spirits that were before the world was, and says, 'These I will make my rulers.' That’s a divine identity moment—God affirming our premortal worth. Notice how this mirrors Moses’s experience of being called 'my son.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s powerful. Where else do we see this?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Jump to the New Testament. Jesus consistently reinforces this identity, teaching in John 1:12 that as many as received Him, 'to them gave he power to become the sons of God.' It’s the same message—our divine potential. And in our day, the Doctrine and Covenants echoes it, like in section 76:24, where we’re called 'begotten sons and daughters unto God.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I never saw that thread so clearly! It’s like a web of divine identity stretching across all these eras. But how does knowing this change how we see Moses’s encounter with Satan?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s where it gets powerful. When Moses resists Satan in Moses 1:13 by saying, 'Who art thou? For behold, I am a son of God,' he’s not just defending himself—he’s claiming a truth that spans eternity. This is why Satan’s attack on identity is so vicious; if we forget who we are, we lose sight of God’s plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s remarkable! Let’s shift gears for a moment. I’m curious about the historical context around Moses’s time. Are there cultural insights that deepen this story?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, and this creates a time collapse moment. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, identity was often tied to lineage and tribal affiliation—think of how Egyptians viewed themselves as descendants of their gods. Moses, raised as an Egyptian prince, would have been steeped in that worldview. So when God calls him 'my son' in Moses 1:4, it’s not just personal—it’s a radical redefinition against everything he’d been taught.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, what? So this is more than just a spiritual truth—it’s a cultural upheaval for Moses?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Precisely. And here’s another layer: ancient texts outside the Bible, like those from Ugarit, show that divine sonship was a concept reserved for kings or gods. God extending that title to Moses—a shepherd at this point—would have been astonishing in that cultural context. It underscores how revolutionary this revelation was.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s mind-blowing. It makes me feel like I’m standing on that mountain with Moses, hearing this for the first time. Now, circling back to that opening mystery—why Satan attacked his identity so directly—what’s the big reveal here?

script.speaker: David
script.text: The reveal is this: identity is the foundation of God’s plan of salvation. Satan attacked Moses’s identity because if Moses doubted his divine sonship, he couldn’t fulfill his mission to lead Israel. It’s the same for us—if we don’t know who we are, we can’t progress toward eternal life, which God defines as His work and glory in Moses 1:39: 'For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a satisfying answer. It ties everything together. But are there other hidden connections in these chapters that most people miss?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Oh, definitely. Notice this in Abraham 3:25, where the Lord says, 'We will prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.' That’s a direct link to Moses’s resistance of Satan—it’s part of the proving process. Our earthly trials, like Moses’s, are designed to test and refine our divine identity.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I hadn’t connected those dots. Is there another one?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, look at Moses 1:30, where Moses asks, 'Tell me, I pray thee, why these things are so, and by what thou madest them?' The Lord’s response in verse 39 about His work and glory connects directly to Abraham 3:24-26, where the plan to create an earth for us to be tested is laid out. It’s all about giving us a chance to become like Him.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s beautiful. It’s like these chapters are two pieces of the same puzzle. So how do these ancient patterns of identity and purpose apply to us today?

script.speaker: David
script.text: They apply directly. Just as Moses had to remember he was a son of God to resist Satan, we need to hold onto that truth when we face doubts or temptations. President Nelson’s teaching in 'Choices for Eternity' reminds us that knowing we’re children of God affects every decision—how we treat others, how we see ourselves, even how we approach trials.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so practical. It makes me think about the choices I make every day. How can we keep this identity at the forefront?

script.speaker: David
script.text: One way is to echo Moses’s response in Moses 1:18, where he calls upon God after resisting Satan. Prayer, scripture study, and even simple reminders—like saying to ourselves, 'I am a child of God'—can anchor us. It’s about daily recommitting to who we really are.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that idea of daily reminders. David, this has been such an enlightening conversation. I’m walking away with a deeper sense of who I am and why that matters.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’m glad, Sarah. And I hope everyone listening feels inspired to look in the mirror and see a child of God, just as Moses did. Let’s keep seeking these truths in the scriptures together.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. Thank you for joining us, David, and thank you to our listeners for being part of this journey. Until next time, keep studying and discovering!
